overview.name: Overview
overview.text:
Assistance needs due to armed conflict and frequent natural disasters include food, healthcare, and protection. With the increase in the number of people internally displaced by conflict and the influx of returnees, shelter and WASH needs have increased significantly. 9.3 million people are in need of humanitarian assistance. However, the high level of insecurity constrains access.
The Taliban increased its influence throughout 2015 – including attacks on provincial capitals towards the end of the year – and this has continued in 2016. The Islamic State (IS) presence has been growing in the east, with significant activity reported in Nangarhar. 
Abuses against Afghans in Pakistan appear to have worsened substantially since June. This has resulted in a mass influx of Afghans from Pakistan back into Afghanistan, putting a strain on the resources and coping capacity of the Afghan government and humanitarian organisations. At the same time, thousands of Afghans are returning from Iran either spontaneously or through deportation, adding to the numbers of internally displaced and people in need in Afghanistan. In the coming months, thousands of Afghan asylum seekers are expected to return as a result of a deal between the European Union and the Afghan government.
INFORM measures Afghanistan’s risk of humanitarian crisis and disaster to be very high, at 7.8/10. Afghanistan’s hazard is of particular concern, at 8.8/10.

figures.name: Returns of Registered Afghan Refugees from Pakistan in 2016
Undocumented Afghan Returnees from Pakistan (since 1 January 2016)

overview.name: Overview
overview.text:
Some 2.9 million people, almost 10% of the population, are in need of humanitarian assistance, primarily in Far North, North, Adamaoua, and East regions. Conflict in both Nigeria and CAR has led to displacement of refugees to Cameroon, but the number of displaced has decreased over the last months. While Boko Haram attacks still occur in the Far North region, they are much less frequent than in the beginning of 2016. Needs remain high in Minawao camp, where 60,200 refugees are living. 
INFORM considers that the risk of humanitarian crisis varies widely, from very high in the Far North to very low in western areas of the country. Nationally, the risk of a humanitarian crisis is at 6.2/10 - a vast increase from 4.6 last year. The hazard and exposure risk stands at 6.8, while its lack of coping capacity is at 6/10.

figures.name: People Assisted with WFP Food Aid (per month)

overview.name: Overview
overview.text:
Failure of the state has resulted in displacement, targeted killings along communal lines, and human rights abuses. Protection, humanitarian access, and food security are priority needs, as continued violence, looting, and displacement cause further deterioration of an already dire humanitarian situation across the country. Insecurity also impedes humanitarian access in the northern and central parts of the country. Needs continue to exceed available resources and delivery of aid is expected to decline because funding remains low.
INFORM measures CAR's risk of humanitarian crisis and disaster to be extremely high, at 8.3/10. CAR's vulnerability is of particular concern.

figures.name: People Assisted with WFP Food Aid (per month)

overview.name: Overview
overview.text:
Over 4.7 million people are in need of humanitarian assistance in Chad, including more than one million expected to be severely food insecure across the country in June.
The country faces security threats on its periphery, most notably from Boko Haram (BH) since February 2015 in Lac region. Attacks have targeted both military operations and civilians, driving people from their homes. More than 120,000 people are displaced in Lac region. Nigerian refugees have been crossing into Chad since 2014, further adding to large refugee populations from Sudan in the east, and Central African Republic in the south.
Underlying vulnerability and food insecurity is high, particularly in the Sahelian zone to the north of the country.
INFORM measures Chad's risk of humanitarian crisis and disaster at 7.76/10, up from 6 in 2016. Hazard and exposureVulnerability as well as lack of coping capacity are of particular concern, at 7.2.4/10 and 8.99/10.

figures.name: Estimated Displaced People, not yet Registered
Children Suffering from Severe Acute Malnutrition

overview.name: Overview
overview.text:
A complex emergency has persisted in DRC for more than 20 years. Conflict between foreign, self-defence, and other armed groups, mainly impacting the eastern provinces, has left the country in a state of prolonged, severe humanitarian crisis. Although the security situation has improved slightly since 2013 when the government defeated M23 in Nord-Kivu, conflict continues. Access remains volatile in the east, and lack of infrastructure is a general problem across the country. Clashes between armed groups and the DRC armed forces are affecting populations mainly in Sud- and Nord-Kivu, Ituri, Tanganyika, and Haut-Katanga provinces. Health is a priority due to recurrent measles, cholera, and malaria outbreaks, and protection concerns are high because of serious human rights violations in the eastern provinces.
In 2016, the ruling coalition has sought to prolong President Joseph Kabila’s time in office beyond December 2016, when his constitutional two-term limit was due to end. A new agreement was reached on 31 December 2016 stating that President Kabila would step down after the next election. Voting is to take place before the end of the year. In 2016, election-related violence increased. Protests related to the forthcoming presidential elections have taken place in Kinshasa, Lubumbashi, Bukavu, and Goma. Election-related human rights violations, including summary executions, death threats, arbitrary detention, and restrictions on freedom of expression and freedom of assembly have been reported since 2015.
INFORM measures DRC's risk of humanitarian crisis and disaster to be very high, at 7/10. Lack of coping capacity is of particular concern, at 8/10 as well as vulnerability at 7/10.

figures.name: People in Food Insecurity and Livelihood Crisis
People Assisted with WFP Food Aid in 2016

overview.name: Overview
overview.text:
Consecutive, below-average rainy seasons have caused severe drought across northern, eastern, and central Ethiopia. This is leading to high levels of food insecurity, particularly in Afar, in Sitti zone of Somali region, and parts of Amhara, Oromia, and SNNPR. Malnutrition has increased significantly. At the same time, there has been flooding throughout the country – Ethiopia generally has a high risk of flood from March - November. As of 12 October, one million Ethiopians are at risk of being affected by flooding of which 45% are expected to be displaced. ?
Hosting over 761,000 refugees from neighbouring countries, including over 300,000 from South Sudan, the majority of Ethiopia’s refugee camps have reached full capacity. Overcrowding, malnutrition, and critical shortfalls in humanitarian aid are of concern. Most refugees have been in protracted displacement, but remain in need of assistance.
A state of emergency was declared on 8 October following large-scale anti-government protests. Protests started in November 2015, and Ethiopian government forces killed least 500 demonstrators in 2016.? 
INFORM measures Ethiopia's risk of humanitarian crisis and disaster to be high, at 6.4/10. Vulnerability is of particular concern, at 6.6/10.

figures.name: South Sudanese Refugees and Asylum-Seekers in Ethiopia

overview.name: Overview
overview.text:
Hurricane Matthew, a Category 4 Hurricane, struck the southwest coast of Haiti at 0700 local time (1200 GMT) on 4 October. Wind speeds of 230km/h were recorded, and caused widespread damage, flooding and displacement. It continued across the northwest of the country.? In total, 2,128,700 people, or 12% of Haiti’s population, have been affected, including 894,100 children.?
Humanitarian needs are already high in Haiti and stem from displacement, food insecurity, and malnutrition. The situation is compounded by an extremely fragile political and economic situation, and a significant vulnerability to natural disasters, including hurricanes, floods, earthquakes, landslides, and droughts. A cholera outbreak has persisted since October 2010.? The resilience of the population is extremely low. Since the beginning of 2015, 80% of Haiti has been affected by El Niño conditions, and around one million Haitians have been affected by drought.
INFORM measures Haiti's risk of humanitarian crisis and disaster at 6.5/10. Hazard and exposure is at 5.4/10. Vulnerability and lack of coping capacity are at alarming levels, with rates of 6.7/10 and 7.5/10.

overview.name: Overview
overview.text:
In 2014, Islamic State (IS) took over significant portions of Iraqi territory, triggering mass displacement and severe humanitarian needs. After a military stalemate throughout much of 2015, government operations to retake territory from Islamic State were stepped up in 2016, aggravating displacement and humanitarian needs, particularly in Anbar and Mosul corridors. Access constraints and human rights violations from all warring parties are of major concern.
Iraq now hosts three million IDPs, one of the largest internally displaced populations in the world. IDPs and Syrian refugees make up 25% of the population in the Kurdistan Region of Iraq (KR-I).
INFORM measures Iraq’s risk of humanitarian crisis and disaster to be very high, at 6.9/10. Hazard and exposure as well as lack of coping capacity are of particular concern, at 7.7/10 and 7/10 rates.

figures.name: Mosul: Families Displaced in Wake of Military Operations
Mosul: Iraqis Displaced to Syria since 17 October 2016

People Assisted with WFP Food Aid

overview.name: Overview
overview.text:
Insecurity persists in Mali, although progress towards the establishment of interim authorities in the north was made between armed groups in late October. Tension still remains between the CMA and the GATIA, signatories of the peace deal signed in 2015, who clashed numerous times in Kidal between July and September. An increase in attacks from Islamist armed groups was reported at the beginning of November. 
Overall, a lack of access to basic social services and the low capacity of public administration drives humanitarian needs. While IDPs and refugees have slowly been returning home since 2013, over 36,700 people remain internally displaced and around 136,000 refugees are still in neighbouring countries. 
INFORM measures Mali's risk of humanitarian crisis and disaster to be very high, at 6.6/10. Hazard and exposure as well as lack of coping capacity and vulnerability are all at alarming levels, at 6.2/10, 6.8/10 and 6.7/10 respectively.

figures.name: Malian Refugees in Burkina Faso, Mauritania and Niger
People Assisted with WFP Food Aid (per month)

overview.name: Overview
overview.text:
Protracted armed conflict between ethnic groups and the government means over 525,500 people are in continued need of assistance, including over 123,300 people in Kachin and Shan states, and 402,000 people in Rakhine state. Access constraints in areas of conflict increase the difficulty of reaching populations in need.
In Rakhine state, discrimination against the Rohingya Muslim minority has caused protracted displacement. IDPs in Rakhine have limited access to services as they are confined to camps. Since 9 October, tensions between the Rohingya and the Myanmar Army have escalated. Security operations by the Myanmar Army since 9 October restrict access to northern Rakhine and have halted all existing aid operations.
The end of 2015 saw landmark elections and a national ceasefire agreement, but several groups are still in armed conflict with the government, predominantly in Kachin, Shan, and Rakhine states.
INFORM measures Myanmar's risk of humanitarian crisis and disaster as very high, at 6.7/10. Hazard and exposure, as well as lack of coping capacity, and vulnerability are all at high levels, at 7.5/10, 6/10 and 6.6/10 respectively.

figures.name: IDPs in Kachin and Northern Shan
People Assisted with WFP Food Aid (per month)

overview.name: Overview
overview.text:
Violence in the northeast has caused massive displacement and at the same time restricted movement: it has disrupted food supplies, seriously hindered access to basic services, and limited agricultural activities. In seven years of conflict, over 20,000 people have been killed in Boko Haram-related incidents. People affected by violence in Adamawa, Borno, and Yobe, and neighbouring Bauchi, Taraba, and Gombe states are in urgent need of food, access to health services, protection, and education. Since February 2016, as humanitarian access is increasing, extreme food insecurity and malnutrition conditions have been revealed in Borno state.
INFORM measures Nigeria's risk of humanitarian crisis and disaster to be high, 6.3/10, and its coping capacity index is 6.6/10.

figures.name: Children Suffering from Severe Acute Malnutrition
People Assisted with WFP Food Aid (per month)

overview.name: Overview
overview.text:
Ensuring the delivery of essential services including healthcare, food, water, and electricity remain of concern across the Gaza strip and the West Bank due to access restrictions imposed by Israel and neighbouring countries. Needs are particularly acute in Gaza, where around 65,000 Palestinians remain displaced from the 50-day war in 2014. The ongoing blockade continues to severely restrict the delivery of services and the movement of people and goods.
INFORM measures Palestine's risk of humanitarian crisis and disaster for 2017 to be at 4.8/10, down from 6.1/10 in 2016. Vulnerability is of particular concern, at 6.3/10.

overview.name: Overview
overview.text: Al Shabaab’s insurgency, coupled with interclan fighting and a severe El Niño-induced drought, has created large-scale displacement and made basic services almost inaccessible for an estimated 5 million Somalis. The INFORM index score for risk of humanitarian catastrophe ranks Somalia at 9.2 out of 10, the highest of any country. Humanitarian access remains extremely limited outside of Somaliland: Lower and Middle Juba regions are particularly inaccessible. The government's control is essentially limited to Mogadishu and surrounding areas, although Al Shabaab attacks in the city persist. The first parliamentary elections since 1967 are scheduled for the end of January 2017, despite political, security, and clan-related challenges. Both the elections and continued insecurity have led to limited national and international response to the ongoing drought, which has spread to new areas of southcentral Somalia, Puntland, and Somaliland.

overview.name: Overview
overview.text:
Since July 2016 there has been a surge in conflict across the country including in previously unaffected areas of Central and Eastern Equatoria. The current situation in these regions is volatile, and there are a large number of displaced. Food insecurity and malnutrition rates are unprecedented, and insecurity is hampering the delivery of assistance. The UN reports widespread violation of human rights and targeted violence against civilians.
Violence spread across eastern and northern South Sudan in December 2013 after President Kiir accused Vice President Riek Machar of plotting a coup. Despite a ceasefire in August 2015, and a transitional government in April 2016. Fighting since July echoes the events that triggered the conflict in 2013, raising concerns of a return to full-scale civil war.
INFORM measures South Sudan's risk of humanitarian crisis and disaster to be extremely high, at 8.3/10. South Sudan's vulnerability is measured at 9.3/10.

figures.name: South Sudanese Refugees in the Region
People in Food Crisis and Emergency
People Assisted by WFP in 2016 (per month)

overview.name: Overview
overview.text:
Protracted insurgencies are being waged by armed groups across Darfur, and persistent conflict situations in South Kordofan and Blue Nile cause high levels of insecurity. Darfur has been the scene of conflict for over a decade, while violence in Blue Nile and South Kordofan increased significantly after South Sudan gained independence in 2011.
Humanitarian access to conflict zones is severely restricted and remains so despite efforts of the AU and UN to broker a peace agreement and ensure increased humanitarian access.
Violence, food insecurity, malnutrition, and lack of access to basic services have caused large-scale internal displacement.
Most recent floods occurred between June and September.
According to INFORM, Sudan is at high risk of being overwhelmed by humanitarian crises and disasters (7/10). Hazard, vulnerability, and a lack of coping capacity are at alarming rates of 7.4/10, 6.6/10, and 7/10.

overview.name: Overview
overview.text:
14.9 million people are in need of humanitarian assistance inside Syria, including 6.3 million IDPs.
Conflict has killed over 310,000 people, including 86,000 civilians, and caused large-scale displacement. Protection concerns are widespread. WASH and access to food are high priorities, as well as access to health services. Humanitarian needs in areas under prolonged and ongoing siege are particularly high as access is obstructed.
Clashes have been ongoing throughout Syria despite a truce agreed by a number of parties at the end of December, and fighting is expected to continue in the coming months. The Turkish army recently increased its activity in Aleppo governorate, targeting both Islamic State and the Kurdish YPG. The governorates of Idlib, Rural Damascus, ar Raqqa, Homs and Hama have been particularly affected in recent weeks.
INFORM measures Syria's risk of humanitarian crisis and disaster to be very high, at 6.9/10. The intensity of highly violent conflict in the country is of particular concern.

figures.name: Registered Syrian Refugees in the Region
Internally Displaced Palestinian Refugees in Syria

overview.name: Overview
overview.text:
Fighting escalated in Yemen in March 2015. 18.8 million people are in need of humanitarian aid, including 10.3 million people in acute need. 
An armed advance on the capital in September 2014 by Houthis from the north has led to civil war throughout the country. A coalition led by Saudi Arabia has supported the Yemeni government with airstrikes since March 2015. Activities by southern secessionists Al Qaeda in the Arabian Peninsula (AQAP) and Islamic State (IS) compound the security and political challenges.
The humanitarian situation is further exacerbated by Yemen’s failing economy. The Central Bank in Yemen is near collapse, putting food imports at risk.
The Inter-Agency Standing Committee (IASC) declared Yemen a Level 3 emergency in July 2015. INFORM measures Yemen's risk of humanitarian crisis and disaster at a very high level of 7.6/10. Hazard and exposure as well as lack of coping capacity and vulnerability are all at alarming levels: 8.2/10, 7.9/10 and 7.8/10 respectively.
